correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding uses the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike-through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: The first release is a reproduction of text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fast: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in the volume Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 7 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p: LOBELIA, L., the typical genus of the tribe Lobelieae, of the order Campanulaceae, named after Matthias de Lobel, a native of Lille, botanist and physician to James I. It numbers about two hundred species, natives of nearly all the temperate and warmer regions of the world, excepting central and eastern Europe as well as western Asia. For the sections into which the genus is divided, see Genera Plantarum, by Bentham and Hooker, vol. ii. p. 551; and for species, De C., Prod., vii. p. 357. Two species are British, L. Dortmanna, L., named after Dortmann, a Dutch druggist, which occurs in gravelly mountain lakes; and L. urens, L., which is only found on heaths, àc., near Axminster (see Baxter’s Brit. Gen,, No. 79). The genus is distinguished from Campanula by the irregular corolla and completely united anthers, and by the excessive acridity of the milky juice. The species earliest described and figured appears to be L. cardinalis, L., under the name Trachelium americanumsive cardinalis planta, “the rich crimson cardinal’s flower”,· Parkinson {Paradisus, 1629, p. 356) says, “it groweth neere the riuer of Canada, where the French plantation in America is seated”; De Candolle records it from New England to Carolina {Prod., vii. 382). This species, as well as several others, are in cultivation as ornamental garden plants, e.g., the dwarf blue E. Ervnus, L, from the Cape, which, with its varieties, forms a familiar Bedding plant. L. splendens, Willd., and L.folgens, Willd., growing from 2 to 4 feet high, from Mexico, have scarlet flowers; while L. amoena, Mich., from North America, as well as L. syphilitica, L., and its hybrids, from Virginia, have blue flowers. The last-named was introduced in 1665, according to Paxton {Bot. Diet., p. 340), but is not mentioned by Parkinson. Certain species of lobelia are used medicinally, the chief being L. inflata, L., a native of north-eastern America, called “Indian tobacco,” as its effects are very similar to those of tobacco; for its localities, &c., see Pickering, ChromHist, of Ph, p. 1015. It is expectorant and diaphoretic in small doses, but in full medicinal doses is nauseating and emetic. It is used for spasmodic asthma, and as an adjunct to diuretics. See Bentley and Trimen’s Med. Pl., No. 162; Pharmacographia, p. 357; and Pereira’s Mat. Med., vol. ii. pt. ii. p. 8. For active principles, see Pharm. Jourm, vol. x. pp. 270, 456. Another medicinal species is L. syphilitica, L., the blue cardinal, of which the root is used by the North American Indians for the purpose implied in the specific name. The value, however, is said to have no foundation in fact (Pearson, Obs. on var. Art. of Mat. Med., p. 70), but see Amer.Dispens., p. 494. A third species is L. decurrens, Cav., from near Arequipa in Peru, where the Indians use it as an emetic {Pharm. Jourm [1], vol. xiii. p. 14).
